Entries.default: "Maia, do you recall the tales or songs of your tribe?"
"I am composing a song for you and Ishiza. It is an ode to Amira, queen of birds."
"For what do you stare at me, little man?"
"You were... a slave? For this fish, the sea means only freedom."
"The gods want more for us than piracy, I say."
"For what do you bury your face in parchment, my friend?"
"Protect your long ears, friend Aloth. The seagulls are restless."
"Uh... no. I was a hatchling when I left the Deadfire."
"I thought perhaps..."
"Another Huana epic? Just wake me up when it's over."
"I... read that your armada fought well at Nakaro Atoll. Neither side left the battle unscathed."
"How's the head, Tekēhu? You... need anything?"
"What do you know, Ishi, the fish boy can read."
"My ink replenishes itself. I am in no physical pain."
"Pretty neat trick, if you ask me."
"I have never seen Ishiza hop to music like that before."
"When fish and bird can befriend each other, anything is possible. I say!"
"This isn't story time, fish boy. Don't make me send Ishiza after your eyes."
"The Huana have done well in this harsh environment. You must concede that."
"They were before they gave their territory to the Vailians."
"You will like it, I think. The tune is inspired by a Rauataian drinking song."
"If... if you must."
"Your... tentacles are making lewd gestures in my direction."
"My apologies. They have a mind of their own."
"Well, it's... kind of cute. In a horrifying way."
"Of course he is a dancer! He takes after his Huana sister."
"He... probably just thought you were gonna feed him."
"I... thank you."
"Thanks all the same. Hearing that from a local feels... important."
"The crown has not called her watershapers to battle in some time."
"We've all seen what happens when Huana get pissed off."
"If I was summoned to sink a Rauataian vessel, I do not think I could answer the call."
"Really? I... promise not to tell anyone."
"Ah... forget that I spoke."
"Tekēhu, do you truly believe Ondra cares for you?"
"Tekēhu, when was the last time the Lady of Lament helped your people?"
"Amira has gifted you beautiful plumage, I say."
"Ekera. She cherishes all her children."
"Perhaps like a child cherishes a doll for a time before she casts it aside for another."
"I say mother Ngati brings in the tide and pulls it back every day."
"For what would I ask anything more of the sea?"
"Di verus? I will never understand how you people can serve something that cares so little for you."
"Per complanca. Do you know how many postenagos have said that to me?"
"Ekera, a sharp beak as well..."
"For what do you scorn the blessing of Amira?"
"If I had feathers, I would preen them to attract a mate."
"Ngati's favor has its... complications, I say."
"Tekēhu, is your... hair... can you trim it... I mean... them?"
"Hylea has done me no favors, so I have done none for her."
"I must concede that the Huana are more welcoming to people of our kind."
"Ac, but you're mistaken. It's a curse, and so I'll hate Hylea for it as long as I draw breath."
"Ekera... the things they teach children these days."
"A mate? We can't have children, postenago. My feathers are as useful as your stupid tentacles."
"Do not listen to her, my little ones."
"Di verus. Being lavished with praise seems terribly difficult."
"Ekera, I tried but once. They would not trust me for weeks after."
"Vrudo! At least my feathers don't have minds of their own."
"I say it is our responsibility to reach out to them first, lady knight."
"Do Huana parents abandon their children where they are born?"
"Ekera, my tribe would be delighted to host a feast in Amira's honor!"
"Sciòderie! The last thing I want is a feast honoring my 'mother'!"
"This 'plumage' brings me only the fawning of boys with bigger eyes than brains."
"This does not happen."
"Strange, no, how the gods are the only ones who do so?"
"For what did I open my mouth and make everything worse...?"
"Your poor ears. Still swollen, I say."
"For what is Eothas the god of light? Does he hold the sun in the sky?"
"Wonderful news, friend Xoti! A sacred coconut beetle is entangled in your hair!"
"For what do you stare at me, priestess?"
"Xoti, I say you stepped on a sacred palm beetle!"
"I say the gods chiseled you from lumber and dragon bone."
"You and the captain traveled together all that time, but never...?"
"You delight in touching exotic animals, ekera?"
"Were I staring? Just be finding your mind a bit... different's, all."
"My thoughts are for myself, but I give of my heart freely."
"There be nets and hooks plenty, lad. I be hoping you stay clear of them."
"A wizard requires a grimoire. Surely you write your chants somewhere."
"What exactly do you think they'll do? Swoop down and nibble my ears?"
"Aye. More than farming, more than fishing, more than shaping the water, even. Freebooting be the means, lad, not the ends."
"Ekera. A hat of kaora reed will guard them better than any helmet."
"Perhaps the birds wouldn't be tempted if the hold didn't smell like fish."
"A balm of crab eggs and beetle paste will clear that up."
"There's virtue in suffering with dignity."
"Yeah, actually. The sun wakes for Eothas - dead or alive. You got a problem with that?"
"Well, don't just watch it lay eggs. Pull it out for me."
"It is a good omen! Let it crawl, I say."
"Fair enough. But if it gets smushed, it ain't my fault."
"It's just... I mean... your, uh, hair. It keeps wriggling around. Like it's got a mind of it's own."
"Do you wish to touch one? They do not bite."
"Would I ever! Hold still. Oh... slimy."
"No, I didn't mean to! Darn it, you think that's bad luck on me now?"
"Ekera, the elders say your nose will fall off into the sand!"
"That's sounds rea - Wait. You wouldn't be pulling my leg now, would you?"
"I'm just saying, I find it funny that all these sacred beetles seem so drawn to me. That makes nine."
"Ekera... the son of trickster Ngati does not wander far from his mother's ways!"
"Still, I should warn you of the tarantula crawling up your back..."
"Nice try. But I ain't falling for this one."
"I do not joke about spiders."
"I'll take that. Least as far as my head's concerned."
"No that's, uh, not how things played out. Just never saw it that way."
"Ngati weeps for such wasted potential."
"Me? I suppose. Much as the next fella."
"Far from these shores lies a garden of anemone. What say we go together?"
"If that's those things that tickle your hands, I'll put the whole Eothas mission aside right now."
"And here with me living the other way round."
"Ekera. He steals the light from others."
"Never! For what would I scribe a song that lives in my heart?"
"You want a bloody nose, fish-face, keep talking."
"Captain, you look most fetching in that color."
"I wish I had seen Caed Nua before the colossus trampled it."
"When you are around I feel the archipelago has more than one savior."
"Would you consider a longer stay in the Deadfire? Island life suits you."
"How many guests could the master bedroom accommodate? Comfortably, I mean."
"It is comforting to surrender the reins to another, I say."
"Caed Nua must have had a dungeon, I say."
"Were guests welcome, or only prisoners?"
"Captain, I say there is something on your cheek."
"Ekera, it was but a kiss. Never fear, I have taken care of it."
"Amira has gifted you beautiful plumage, I say."
"Maia, do you recall the tales or songs of your tribe?"
"Captain... a word?"
"Captain... a word?"
